text.4:
Allah bestows His favor by instilling tranquility in the hearts of those who believe, especially in the hearts of the Companions who accompanied the Messenger of Allah (saw) in the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah. With that tranquility of heart, the Companions obeyed Allah's law and the decisions of His Messenger. With that tranquility of heart, Allah also increased the faith of the Companions.

Imam al-Bukhari establishes a conclusion based on this verse that faith is not of the same degree in every believer's heart; some is strong, some is moderate, and some is weak. In addition, faith can also increase and decrease in a person.

Some commentators of the Quran are of the opinion that what is meant by lowering tranquility into the hearts of the believers is eliminating the differences of opinion that occurred among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (saw) regarding the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah. With the emergence of tranquility of heart, all the Companions of the Prophet eventually followed the decision of the Messenger of Allah. It is narrated that 'Umar bin al-Khaththab was among the Companions who did not agree with the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, so he said, "Are we not on the path of truth, while they are on the path of falsehood?" With the mercy of Allah, that difference of opinion disappeared. The Companions realized the truth of the opinion of the Messenger of Allah (saw), including 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, who eventually agreed with the opinion of the Messenger of Allah.

This verse can have a general meaning and can also have a specific meaning. In a general sense, this verse means that Allah will instill tranquility of heart, patience, and steadfastness in every believer so that there will be no more differences of opinion among them that can cause division. Only those who are lacking in faith are easily at odds with other believers. While the specific meaning is that Allah creates tranquility of heart in everyone who was with the Messenger of Allah (saw) in facing the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah. This specific meaning is what is meant in this verse because it is in accordance with the reason for its revelation.

Allah explains that He is the One who regulates and controls the heavens and the earth. He has "armies of the heavens" and "armies of the earth," which can carry out everything He wills. Not one of His armies denies His command. Among these "armies" are angels, animals, hurricanes, devastating earthquakes, floods, various kinds of diseases, and so on. If Allah wills, He can destroy everything with just one type of His army, including destroying Satan. But He does not do so; rather, He commands the Muslims to strive and fight in His way (jihad). All of this is determined in accordance with the wisdom, purpose, and benefit that He knows, while humans may not know it.
text.5:
It is narrated by Imam Ahmad and al-Bukhari that Anas bin Malik asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) about the revelation of verses 1 to 3 of this surah, on the way back to Medina, after the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Indeed, a verse has been revealed to me that is more beloved to me than anything on the face of the earth." Then he recited it. The companions said, "How wonderful, O Messenger of Allah, indeed it has been explained what will be bestowed upon you, but what will Allah bestow upon us?" Then this verse was revealed, explaining the blessings that will be received by those who believe.

The Muslims who pledged allegiance to the Prophet Muhammad and accepted the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah obtained an even greater addition of blessings from Allah by erasing the sins and mistakes they had committed and providing a place full of happiness for them in Paradise. This was a great victory for them.
text.6:
The pledge (Baiat) of the Muslims to the Prophet, and the acceptance of the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, were made by Allah as reasons to:

1.  Punish the hypocrites and the polytheists, both men and women, with defeat in this world, in addition to the confusion, fear, and sadness that arose within them upon seeing the victory of the Muslims over them, the capture of some of them by the believers, the killing of some of their families in battle, and so on. Initially, they thought they would surely win and defeat the Muslims, even being able to kill them all. At that time, they were convinced that their situation was better than that of the Muslims. But the opposite happened, and all their regrets were of no use.

2.  Anger them, so that their lives would be miserable in this world and the hereafter.

3.  Curse them, so that they would be tormented in this world.

4.  Admit them into Hell (Jahanam).

In this verse, "the hypocrites" are mentioned before "the polytheists." The wisdom behind this is to emphasize that the hypocrites cause more harm to the believers than the polytheists do. The hypocrite is an invisible enemy and difficult to deal with, while the polytheists are clearly visible enemies, making them easier to confront. Regarding the attitude of these hypocrites, Allah says:

"Nay, you thought that the Messenger and the believers would never return to their families, and that was made pleasing in your hearts, and you thought an evil thought and you were a ruined people." (al-Fath/48: 12)

In addition to disaster, the hypocrites and the polytheists will also receive the wrath of Allah, be distanced from His mercy, and have Hell (Jahanam) prepared for them, which will burn them to ashes in the hereafter. Hell (Jahanam) is the worst place prepared for them.
text.7:
It is narrated that after the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, Ibn Ubayy said, "Does Muhammad think that after the peace of Hudaybiyyah, he no longer has any enemies? Are there not still the kingdoms of Persia and Rome?" Then this verse was revealed, explaining that Allah has armies of the heavens and the earth, which can defeat any army or power if He wills it.

The hypocrites and polytheists will not be able to challenge Allah's power and will because He has strong armies in the heavens and on earth, consisting of angels, jinn, humans, powerful lightning, strong winds, floods, devastating earthquakes, and so on. All of these can be mobilized by Allah whenever He wills to destroy those who disbelieve in Him.

In verse 4, it has also been explained that Allah has armies in the heavens and on earth. In this verse, the statement is repeated. Its function is to explain that Allah has armies to deliver mercy and send down His punishment. Verse 4 explains the armies that deliver blessings, while this verse explains the armies that send down punishment.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that Allah is All-Mighty, nothing can defeat or match Him. He is All-Wise, carrying out all kinds of actions according to their benefits and advantages.
text.8: Allah states that indeed He sent Muhammad as a witness over his ummah regarding the truth of Islam and the success of the da'wah that he carried out. The Prophet was tasked with conveying the religion of Allah to all people, as well as delivering good news to those who are willing to follow the religion he conveyed. Those who follow the invitation of the Messenger will be given a multiplied reward in the form of Paradise in the Hereafter. The Prophet was also tasked with giving a warning to those who deny his call to follow the religion of Allah that they will be put into Hell as a result of that denial.
text.9: Allah does this so that people may believe in Him and in Muhammad, peace be upon him, as the messenger He sent; defend and uphold His religion by conveying it to other people; glorify Him by magnifying His name; and glorify Him by praising and sanctifying Him from attributes that are not befitting of Him every morning and evening.
text.10:
This verse explains Allah's statement regarding the bai'at (pledge of allegiance) made by the Companions to the Messenger of Allah (saw), stating that it also meant making bai'at to Allah. Bai'at is a pledge of allegiance or a declaration made by one or more people containing an acknowledgment to obey someone, for example, because he has been appointed as a leader or caliph.

The bai'at referred to in this verse is Bai'atur Ridhwan, which took place in Hudaibiyyah, made by the Companions under the Samurah tree. At that time, the Companions pledged to the Messenger of Allah (saw) that they would not flee from the battlefield and would fight to the last drop of blood against the polytheists of Mecca, if the news conveyed to them that 'Uthman bin 'Affan, who was sent by the Messenger, had indeed been killed by the polytheists of Mecca.

Narrated by al-Bukhari from Qatadah that he said to Sa'id bin al-Musayyab, "What was the number of people who participated in Bai'ah ar-Ridhwan?" Sa'id replied, "One thousand five hundred people." Some also believe the number was one thousand four hundred people.

In this verse, the method of bai'at performed by the Companions to the Messenger of Allah (saw) is explained, namely by placing the Messenger's hand on the hands of those who pledged. In this position, the word bai'at was uttered.

The meaning of the phrase "the hand of Allah is above their hands" is to state that making a pledge with the Messenger of Allah (saw) is the same in law as making a pledge to Allah. The hand of Allah in the context of this verse is a figurative meaning, because Allah is Exalted above all attributes that resemble His creation. Therefore, some scholars of tafsir interpret the hand here as power.

Then, the consequences that will be experienced by those who break the agreement are explained, namely that they will bear a great sin. This great sin is imposed on them because they refused to give bai'at to the Prophet (saw), while the Muslims gave bai'at to him personally. Conversely, the rewards that will be obtained by those who fulfill their bai'at are also explained. They will receive manifold rewards in the Hereafter, and their place is Paradise, full of delights.
text.11:
Allah explained to the Messenger of Allah (saw) that some Arab tribes, inhabitants of the desert who did not go to Mecca to perform umrah, would say to him, "We did not go with you to Mecca to perform umrah because we were busy taking care of our work, wealth, and families. And we do not have any helpers who will help us take care of all of that after we leave with you. Therefore, ask forgiveness for us from your Lord, citing our busyness as the reason."

When the Messenger of Allah (saw) decided to go to Mecca to perform umrah in the sixth year of the Hijrah, he invited the Muslims to go with him. The more who went with him, the greater the significance, because the large number of Muslims would instill fear in the hearts of the polytheists of Mecca, so that they would allow the Muslims to enter Mecca, and the umrah could be performed in a safe atmosphere. Among the Muslims who were invited were Arab tribes living in the desert around the city of Medina, such as the tribes of Juhainah, Muzainah, Gifar, Asyja', ad-Dil, and Aslam. The Messenger of Allah (saw) stated to them that the purpose of going to Mecca was solely to perform the act of worship of umrah and to see family that had been left behind for a long time. Therefore, the departure to Mecca was not with complete weapons as for going to war, except for carrying weapons that were usually carried by travelers. In addition, livestock were also brought for food on the journey and to be given as gifts to the people of Mecca. Even so, their invitation was still rejected by them with the reasons they put forward above, even though they were hiding the real reason.

Even though the Arab people of the desert tried to hide their real reason, Allah is All-Knowing of everything. Therefore, Allah informed the Messenger of Allah (saw) about it. Their real reason was their assumption that the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the Muslims would be defeated and completely annihilated by the polytheists of Mecca. If they went with the Messenger of Allah, of course they would also be defeated and completely annihilated. This reason and the contents of their hearts were conveyed by Allah to the Messenger of Allah (saw) before they came to him to ask for forgiveness from Allah for their rejection. Thus, the Messenger of Allah had known the true contents of their hearts at the time they came before him.

Allah then taught the Messenger of Allah the appropriate answer to convey to them when they asked him to ask Allah for forgiveness for their sins. Allah taught the Prophet by commanding him to say to the Arab people of the desert as a rejection of their request, "O Arab people of the desert, you rejected my invitation to go to Mecca solely because you wanted to avoid the disaster and calamity that you thought would befall you. Who among you is able to resist the power of Allah if He wills to inflict disaster and calamity upon you, and who can prevent something that He will give to someone, if He wills it? No one is able to do it. Therefore, it is not appropriate for you to put forward the reason that you are busy taking care of your affairs, wealth, and guarding your family as a reason for not going with me to Mecca. If Allah wants to destroy everything you own, no one can defend it, even if you are the one guarding it."

This verse is also a warning to people who always put forward "worldly busyness" as a reason for abandoning religious obligations that Allah has imposed on them and for violating Allah's prohibitions that have been warned to them. Muslims should be absolutely certain that worldly busyness is only to achieve temporary worldly pleasures, while *jihad fi sabilillah* will produce eternal happiness in the afterlife.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is All-Knowing of everything that His servants do, including the false reasons put forward by someone to avoid the commands of Allah. Therefore, He will give a fair and appropriate reward to every human being for all the sins and deeds that have been done.
text.12: In this verse, Allah explains that the desert Arabs have been consumed by the deception of Satan. The assumption that the Messenger of Allah (saw) and his companions would be destroyed had truly been planted by Satan in their hearts, to the point that it had become their opinion and belief. Therefore, they were very afraid to go with the Messenger of Allah to Mecca. However, if they had thought about it deeply, their reluctance would actually be the cause of their destruction in this world, let alone in the Hereafter. The place prepared for them is a blazing Hellfire.
text.13: In this verse, it is stated that whoever does not believe in Allah and His Messenger, then Allah will prepare for them a blazing fire as a recompense for their denial.
text.14:
Allah's threat to punish the disbelievers is not a fabricated threat that is difficult to carry out, but something that will truly happen and is easy for Allah to implement because He alone is the ruler of the heavens and the earth and all that is in them. He alone possesses, regulates, manages, establishes the laws that apply to them, and maintains their existence with perfect wisdom. He also has the right to forgive, help, and punish whom He wills. He is Allah, the Most Forgiving and Everlasting in His mercy.

This verse indicates that even though the Arab people of the desert have rejected and denied the invitation of the Messenger of Allah (saw) to go to Mecca and fabricated reasons for their non-attendance, Allah is Most Forgiving to servants who repent to Him with sincere repentance. Therefore, it depends on them whether they want to repent at the opportunity that Allah has given or whether they will remain disbelievers. He will bestow boundless mercy upon everyone who sincerely worships Him.
text.15:
The Bedouin Arabs who did not participate in the Umrah to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he was about to go to Khaybar, "O Muhammad, give us the opportunity to join you to Khaybar." Their willingness to go to Khaybar was because they were sure that the Battle of Khaybar would be won by the Muslims, so they would obtain a lot of spoils of war in that battle.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions went to the battlefield of Khaybar in the month of Muharram in the seventh year after his return from the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah. In that battle, the Muslims were victorious and obtained a lot of spoils of war from the Jews.

In a sahih hadith, it is explained that Allah had promised the companions who went with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to Hudaybiyyah that they would be victorious in the Battle of Khaybar and obtain a lot of spoils of war. This promise indirectly rejects the willingness of the Bedouin Arabs who wanted to fight with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) because this war was specifically for the Muslims who went to Hudaybiyyah.

Because of their bad intentions, Allah commanded the Messenger to say to those who were willing to go to Khaybar, but did not go to Hudaybiyyah, "You do not need to come with us to Khaybar because you already know us. You only want to join if you will get personal gain, while if there is no gain, but only misery and disaster, then you do not want to go with us, and even give various reasons. Thus, Allah has revealed the secrets of your hearts to us before we returned from Hudaybiyyah and Allah has declared to us that the spoils of Khaybar will only be received by those who went to Hudaybiyyah, that is why you are not allowed to come with us."

The Bedouin Arabs replied, "O Muhammad, you are making a lie against us. Actually, Allah did not say that. You are making that lie solely because of the envy that arises in your heart towards us." At the end of this verse, it is explained that the hypocritical Bedouin Arabs who said that are people who do not know the religion of Allah. They also do not know the purpose of the command of jihad. Allah commanded jihad not because He is unable to destroy them, but to distinguish who among them believes and who disbelieves.
text.16:
This verse seems to test the hearts and will of the hypocritical Bedouin Arabs, by commanding the Messenger of Allah to say that if they truly wanted to join the ranks of the Muslims, they would be invited to fight against people of great strength. They would be required to fight the enemy unless they surrendered and embraced Islam.

Then, these Bedouin Arabs were promised that if they participated in jihad, Allah would bestow His blessings upon them, both in this world in the form of victory and spoils of war, and in the Hereafter in the form of a paradise full of delights. Conversely, if they disobeyed Allah's command, refused to participate in jihad, and failed to carry out that command, they would receive a painful punishment in the Hereafter.

With this verse, it is as if Allah is giving them an opportunity to repent by accepting the invitation to jihad. However, on their faces appeared denial and fear of accepting the invitation and the opportunity to repent.

The meaning of "people of great strength" here is the disbelievers of Mecca. While according to some others, it means the Hawazin and Bani Hanifah tribes in Nejed.
text.17:
It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that when the verse threatening those who refused to participate in jihad with the Messenger of Allah was revealed, the paralyzed people said, "What about us, O Messenger of Allah?" In response, this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah explains that permissible reasons for someone not to participate in warfare are blindness, lameness, physical disability, or illness. Muqatil said, "The Prophet (saw) justified the reasons of the sick for not joining the Messenger of Allah to Hudaibiyyah based on this verse."

Then Allah gives encouragement and enthusiasm to the believers that whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger, and fulfills the call to jihad in His path, will be rewarded with a paradise full of delights. Conversely, those who deny Allah and His Messenger and refuse to participate in jihad with other Muslims, Allah will punish them with a painful torment.
text.18:
Allah informed the Messenger of Allah (saw) that He was pleased with the pledge (bai'at) that the companions had made to him during Bai'ah ar-Ridhwan. The companions who participated in the pledge at that time numbered approximately 1,400. According to a narration, there was one person who accompanied the Messenger of Allah (saw) but did not participate in the pledge, namely Jadd bin Qais al-Ansari. He was a hypocrite.

The companions who made the pledge had promised to fulfill all the promises they had made, even if it resulted in their own deaths. This is mentioned in a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari from Salamah bin al-Akwa', who said:

"I made a pledge to the Messenger of Allah (saw), then I walked towards the shade of a tree (Samurah). When the people began to thin out, the Prophet (saw) said, 'O Ibn al-Akwa', have you not made a pledge?' I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, I have already made a pledge.' The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, 'This one too.' So I made a pledge for the second time." I (Yazid bin Abu 'Ubaid, one of the narrators of this hadith) asked Salamah bin al-Akwa', "O Abu Muslim (Salamah's nickname), what did you pledge for on that day?" He replied, "To die." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Salamah bin al-Akwa')

Allah promised a reward in the form of Paradise full of delights to those who participated in the pledge. This is also affirmed in a hadith of the Messenger of Allah (saw) narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, Abu Dawud, and at-Tirmidhi from Jabir (r.a.), the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"No one who participated in the pledge under the tree (Samurah) will enter Hellfire."

According to Nafi', when 'Umar bin al-Khaththab heard that the companions frequently came to visit the tree to commemorate and remember the event of Bai'ah ar-Ridhwan, he ordered that the tree be cut down. Umar ordered that the tree and the place not be sanctified and worshiped by people who came later, so that it would become a place where shirk would arise. Umar's action was as *saddu dhari'ah* (blocking the means or opportunity to prevent shirk from occurring in the future).

Furthermore, Allah explains that He knows the contents of the hearts and the determination of the Muslims who made the pledge. Therefore, Allah instilled in their hearts tranquility, patience, and obedience to the decisions of the Messenger of Allah (saw). Allah also promised them victory in the Battle of Khaibar, which occurred in the near future. Thus, this verse is one of the verses that explain events that will occur in the future, namely the victory of the Muslims in the Battle of Khaibar. And that event really happened.
text.19:
This verse explains that in the Battle of Khaybar, which was about to occur, the Muslims would achieve victory over the disbelievers and obtain abundant spoils of war. These spoils were specifically given to the Muslims who participated in the Bai'ah ar-Ridhwan (Pledge of Good Pleasure).

At the end of this verse, Allah repeats His threat to the hypocritical Bedouin Arabs who refused to accompany the Messenger of Allah (saw) to Mecca. Allah will impose something upon His creation in accordance with His wisdom and benefit.
text.20:
Allah promises victory and abundant spoils of war to the Muslims from the disbelievers gradually in the future. Allah will soon grant victory and spoils of war in the Battle of Khaybar. Allah also guarantees and prevents the Jews in Medina from disturbing and damaging the property of the Muslims when they go to Mecca and Khaybar. These events should be gratefully acknowledged and used as evidence of the truth of Prophet Muhammad as a messenger sent by Allah to mankind. Allah helps and assists the Muslims from the threats and attacks of enemies, whether their arrival is known or not, in large or small numbers. Allah guides the Muslims to tread the straight path that is pleasing to Him.

According to Ibn Jarir, what is meant by the statement, "Allah restrained the hands of people who would destroy the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims" is the desire and effort of the people of Khaybar and other tribes allied with them, because in their hearts there was still envy and resentment. The tribes allied with the people of Khaybar were the tribes of Asad and Ghatafan.
text.21:
Besides victory and a guarantee of security, Allah also promises that the Muslims will conquer other lands that have not yet been conquered. Allah has ensured that these lands can be controlled by the Muslims and protected from the possibility of being conquered by others. The truth of Allah's promise was proven later, with the conquest of lands around the Arabian Peninsula such as Persia, and parts of the Roman Empire.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He has power that cannot be matched by anyone, and nothing is difficult for Him. It is as if with this verse, Allah is stating that granting victory to the Muslims over the disbelievers is not a difficult thing for Him. If He wills it, it will surely happen.
text.22: In this verse, Allah gives glad tidings to the Muslims that if the Quraysh attacked the Muslims at Hudaibiyyah, He would surely help them and destroy the polytheist forces. Allah also declares that the Muslims will be able to conquer Mecca in the near future. This is depicted in His saying, "O Muslims, if the people of Mecca were to fight you and refuse to accept the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah, We would surely defeat them, and they would retreat and flee in disarray, because they have no helpers or protectors to defend them. But you, O Muslims, have helpers and protectors to achieve victory."
text.23: This verse affirms that establishing faith over disbelief and eradicating falsehood with truth has become a *sunnah* (law) of Allah that applies to all of His creations from the past until the present, and for the future. None of the creatures in this universe can change His *sunnah*.
text.24:
It was narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Abi Shaybah, 'Abd bin Humaid, Muslim, Abu Dawud, and an-Nasa'i, from Anas bin Malik, that he said, "During the Battle of Hudaibiyyah, 80 polytheists of Mecca, fully armed, attacked the encampment of the Messenger of Allah and his companions from the hill of Tan'im. Thanks to the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (saw), the attack was thwarted and all the invaders were captured. Then the Messenger of Allah (saw) freed and forgave them, and this verse was revealed."

Allah is the One who restrained and hindered the attack of the polytheists who attacked the encampment of the Messenger of Allah at Hudaibiyyah, and Allah is also the One who promised victory to the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the Muslims. Then He also instilled in the heart of the Messenger of Allah (saw) a sense of compassion and mercy, so that he freed the captured disbelievers. Not one of them was killed, even though the Muslims had achieved victory.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is All-Knowing of all that His creatures do, nothing is hidden from Him. Therefore, He will reward all their deeds with a fitting and just recompense.
text.25:
This verse explains that the disbelievers hindered the Muslims from performing Umrah at the Masjidilharam. They also prevented the Muslims from bringing and slaughtering sacrificial animals in the area around the Masjidilharam, such as in Mina and so on.

As has been explained, in the sixth year of the Hijrah, the Messenger of Allah (saw) departed for Mecca with a group of companions to perform Umrah and slaughter sacrificial animals in the haram area. Because they were bound by the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah, the Messenger of Allah (saw) and his companions could not fulfill their intention that year. The Messenger tried to abide by the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah, but a group of polytheists attacked the camp of the Messenger of Allah (saw) in Hudaibiyyah, but the attack was thwarted by Allah. Even so, many of the Muslims wanted to retaliate for the attack, even though they were bound by the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah. Allah softened the hearts of the Muslims so that they accepted the decision of the Messenger of Allah. Allah explained that He softened the hearts of the Muslims so that they would not attack Mecca for two reasons: first, to save the Muslims in Mecca who were concealing their faith from the disbelievers. They were afraid of being killed or persecuted by the disbelievers if they declared their faith. The Muslims themselves could not distinguish them from the disbelievers. If an attack on the city of Mecca occurred, the believers in Mecca would certainly be killed like the disbelievers. If that happened, the Muslims would be afflicted with shame and difficulty because they would have to pay *kifarat* (expiation). The polytheists would also say, "Indeed, the Muslims have killed people who share their religion."

Second, there was an opportunity for the Muslims to invite the polytheists to believe. With the occurrence of the Treaty of Hudaibiyyah, the Muslims were able to communicate directly with the disbelievers. Thus, a reasonable exchange of ideas could occur between them, without pressure from any party, so that it could be hoped that certain people whose conversion was hoped for would embrace Islam, or that their attitude would no longer be as harsh as before. It was hoped that these things would happen before the Muslims performed Umrah in the coming year.

From this verse, it can be understood that Allah always protects and safeguards those who truly believe in Him, wherever they may be. He will not even inflict a disaster on the disbelievers if there are believers who would be affected by that disaster.
text.26:
This verse reminds the Muslims of the arrogance and pride that arose in the hearts of the polytheists of Mecca. This feeling arose when they disagreed with writing "Bismillahir-Rahmanir-Rahimi" at the beginning of the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah.

It is narrated that when the Messenger of Allah (saw) intended to fight the polytheists, they sent Suhail bin 'Amr, Khuwaithib bin 'Abd al-'Uzza, and Mikras bin Hafadz to him. They conveyed a request to him to abandon his intention, and they agreed if that intention was carried out in the coming year. Thus, they would have the opportunity to empty the city of Mecca at the time when the Muslims performed Umrah and would not be disturbed by anyone. So a treaty was made. The Messenger of Allah (saw) ordered 'Ali bin Abi Talib to write "Bismillahir-Rahmanir-Rahimi". They replied, "We do not know it." The Messenger of Allah said that this agreement was a sign of peace from him to the people of Mecca. They said, "If we acknowledged that you are the Messenger of Allah, we would not hinder you and would not fight you, and write this agreement as a sign of peace from Muhammad bin Abdullah to the people of Mecca." So the Messenger of Allah (saw) said to his companions, "Write it according to their wishes."

Because of their attitude, some of the Muslims were reluctant to accept the treaty and wanted to invade the city of Mecca. So Allah instilled tranquility and an attitude of obedience and submission in the companions to the decision of the Messenger of Allah (saw).

Everything that happened, both among the believers and among the disbelievers, was known to Allah; nothing escapes His knowledge. Therefore, He will reward every deed and action of His servants with the utmost justice.
text.27: Allah clarifies that the Messenger of Allah's dream, in which he saw himself and his companions entering the city of Mecca safely and peacefully, and he also saw some of his companions cutting and shaving their hair, was a true dream and would certainly come to pass in the near future.
text.28:
In this verse, the truth of Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a messenger sent by Allah to humanity is affirmed by stating that he is the messenger of Allah sent to bring guidance and the religion of Islam as a completion of the religions and laws brought by previous messengers, to declare the errors and mistakes of religious creeds and beliefs held by people that are not based on religion, and to establish laws that apply to humans according to the development of the times, differences in circumstances and places. This also means that with the coming of the religion of Islam brought by Muhammad (peace be upon him), other religions are no longer recognized as valid religions in the sight of Allah.

At the end of this verse, it is stated that everything Allah has promised to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and the Muslims will surely happen and nothing can prevent it from happening.
text.29:
This verse explains that Muhammad saw is the Messenger of Allah sent to all people. The companions and followers of the Messenger were harsh towards the disbelievers, but gentle towards each other. Allah says:

"O you who have believed, whoever of you should revert from his religion - Allah will bring forth [in place of them] a people He will love and who will love Him, humble toward the believers, powerful against the disbelievers, striving in the way of Allah..." (al-Ma'idah/5: 54)

The Messenger of Allah said:

"The likeness of the believers in their mutual love, mercy and compassion is that of a (single) body; when one of its limbs aches, the whole body feels the pain with fever and restlessness." (Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad from an-Nu'man bin Basyir)

The believers always perform the prayer with humility, submission, and sincerity, seeking reward, grace, and the pleasure of Allah. Traces of prostration are visible on their faces. This means a radiant countenance, without any indication of envy or ill intentions towards others, full of submission and obedience to Allah, with refined behavior and character as a reflection of their faith.

Regarding the light on the faces of the believers, 'Uthman said, "As for the secret hidden in a person's heart; surely Allah will reveal it on his face and tongue." Such qualities are described in the Torah and the Gospel.

The companions and followers of the Prophet were initially few and weak, then they increased and grew rapidly like a seed that grows, sprouts its stem, then the stem branches and twigs, then becomes large and fruitful, astonishing those who planted it, because of its strength and beauty, thus increasing the anger of the disbelievers.

Then to the followers of the Messenger of Allah saw, both past and present, Allah promises forgiveness for their sins, gives them abundant rewards, and provides Paradise as an eternal abode for them. Such a promise from Allah is certainly fulfilled.
